title: Millennials may be the key to nuclear power
text:
Younger Australians represent a great hope for the establishment of a domestic nuclear industry because they are prepared to accept independent information about the controversial energy, Australia's top nuclear advocate said.

Mark Ho, the president of the Australian Nuclear Association, told The Australian Financial Review National Energy Summit that nuclear power was possible within 10 to 15 years if legal bans could be lifted at the state and federal level.

The OPAL nuclear reactor in Western Sydney and operated by a federal government agency.

"Public perception is improving," he said. "We're seeing a generational change in terms of the outlook in nuclear power. Millennials and young people take news and facts from a wider variety and all the facts are out there."

Dr Ho, a nuclear engineer at the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, cited a survey published this week by Roy Morgan Research that found 51 per cent of people support nuclear if they are told it will reduce emissions of carbon dioxide.

Support is up 16 percentage points since 2011, and suggests that long-held opposition to nuclear power in Australia is slowing dying out as people who grew up in the Cold War, when nuclear war was seen as possible, get older. One third of people reject nuclear power, down 24 percentage points from 2011, Roy Morgan found.
description: Opposition to nuclear reactors has dropped sharply as Australians shaped by the Cold War are replaced by less fearful generations.
